abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Vocational
            Training Project for Pakistan was unsatisfactory. The
            project achieved some of its objectives, its impact on
            institutional development has been partially successful,
            sustainability is unlikely, and the performance of the Bank
            was satisfactory while the Borrower's was negligible.
            Several lessons can be learned from this project. First,
            public sector interventions in the training sector should
            essentially be catalytic in nature to create a participative
            environment where training providers and employers work in
            tandem. Second, policymakers and planners need a greater
            understanding of the dynamics of job creation and
            job-related training. Third, the informal sector
            complemented by enterprise-based training will continue to
            remain a major source of trained manpower in Pakistan for a
            long time. Fourth, the expansion of the training sector
            should not be governed by compulsions of social demand for
            vocational training opportunities but instead by the
            imperatives of economic demand. Fifth, multi-sectoral policy
            setting and coordinating bodies entrusted with a normative
            charter but without legislated empowerment have little
            potential of coming to life. Sixth, recurrent operation
            budgets are likely to remain short-funded in the short and
            medium terms. Finally, the full benefits of mid-term
            restructuring of a project can accrue only if sufficient
            time is allowed for the restructured components to develop
            institutional strength.

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of the Second
            Vocational Training Project are to improve the quality and
            expand the capacity of the vocational training system to
            meet the requirements for skilled and semi-skilled manpower
            in the industrial and rural sectors.  The system will be
            expanded by:  (a) re-equipping existing vocational training
            centers and introducing additional programs; (b) developing
            new vocational training centers in rural areas; and (c)
            strengthening the existing provincial apprenticeship system
            to expand in-plant training programs.  The quality will be
            improved by:  (a) expanding the National Training
            Development Institute to provide instructor training; and
            (b) further strengthening the management and project
            implementation capacity of the National and Provincial
            Training Boards.  The project will also establish a pilot
            and experimental program of Women's Technical Training Centers.
